items.title: SyntaxWarning due to comparison of literals using is in Python 3.8
Help writing a programmatic TermList
items.body:
Howdy!  
I'm iterating through competing GAM models, and need some help writing more flexible TermLists.
I have a list of candidate effects: 
`eff = ['x1', 'x2', 'x3']`
And for each I have a known term:
`terms = ['LinearTerm', 'SplineTerm(n_splines=15)', "FactorTerm(coding='dummy')"]`
Right now, I have to construct the terms explicitly; e.g.,
`gam = LinearGam(l(0) + s(1, n_splines=15) + f(2, coding='dummy'))`
When I want to permute the terms to, say, keep only terms 0 and 3, I have to rewrite.  I'd love to construct an iterator, or better a dictionary of combinations and then pass each combination to a `GAM()` call.

I've looked at `pygam.terms.TermList.build_from_info()`, but can't figure out the right syntax.  
Any help would be greatly appreciated!

items.title: Can I develop a GAMM(Generalized Additive Mixed  Models) in this package?

```
N/A% (0 of 11) |                         | Elapsed Time: 0:00:00 ETA:  --:--:--/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/pygam/links.py:149: RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in true_divide
```

items.title: Why confidence band intersect?
items.body:
hi, pyGAM team!
@dswah 
thanks to your nice tool.

i train a data set and plot figs of every feature with confidence interval, but i got some interesting result. the confidence band **intersect** .

see figs:

![confuse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24653173/55309931-be3a6580-5491-11e9-9760-28da39f5c111.PNG)
and code is here

```py
j = 0
for i, term in enumerate(gam.terms):
    if term.isintercept:
        continue

    XX = gam.generate_X_grid(term=i)
    pdep, confi = gam.partial_dependence(term=i, X=XX, width=0.95)
    plt.subplot(r,c,i+1)
    plt.plot(XX[:, term.feature], pdep)
    plt.plot(XX[:, term.feature], confi, c='r', ls='--')
    plt.title(headers[j])
    j+=1
```

so i'd like to know if there are some bugs in the code or some other statistical analysis ?

thanks again!

items.title: Constraint to obtain non-negative predict( ) output?
items.body: I recently started using pygam and based on the docs there does not seem to be an explicit constraint I can use to constrain output from the `gam.predict` as positive. Would you know of any alternate approach I could take to constrain my output to only positive values? Thanks.

items.title: [Question] Why PIRLS?
items.body: I see PyGAM uses a modified Iteratively reweighted least squares. Since there's not much in the documentation about it, I wondered if there's any quick explanation for that. How does it differ, in the case of GAM's, from say, Newton's, or BFGS?

items.title: add dummy coding for categorical variables
items.body:
variables with `n` categories have only `n-1` degrees of freedom. 

stricter treatment of categorical variables will reduce statistical problems and reduce computational burden. 

see:
https://github.com/dswah/pyGAM/issues/209#issuecomment-424775104

items.title: gam.summary() - return String rather than "printing" to standard out
items.body:
Or add another method that returns as String to retain backwards compatibility. 

This would enable easier saving of statistics to the file system, which can be more useful if incorporating pyGAM into a pipeline. 

Currently I'm having to redirect stdout, which works, but it's a bit inelegant. 

Thanks!

items.title: How to interpret the `coef_` attribute from a fitted model?
items.body:
I am trying to understand the tutorial: https://codeburst.io/pygam-getting-started-with-generalized-additive-models-in-python-457df5b4705f

How can I interpret the `coef_`?  Why are there 121 coefficients with 6 attributes? 

```python
import pandas as pd        
from pygam import LogisticGAM
from sklearn.datasets import load_breast_cancer

#load the breast cancer data set
data = load_breast_cancer()
#keep first 6 features only
df = pd.DataFrame(data.data, columns=data.feature_names)[['mean radius', 'mean texture', 'mean perimeter', 'mean area','mean smoothness', 'mean compactness']]
y = pd.Series(data.target)
X = df[['mean radius', 'mean texture', 'mean perimeter', 'mean area','mean smoothness', 'mean compactness']]

#Fit a model with the default parameters
gam = LogisticGAM().fit(X, y)
X.shape, gam.coef_.shape
# ((569, 6), (121,))
```

items.title: Order of spline
items.body:
In earlier versions of pyGAM I was able to set the spline_order parameter, which signifies the order of the spline I want to fit. That way I could specify if I want a linear spline, a cubic spline or higher.

1. Is there still a provision to specify the order of the spline?

2. Does the model output (summary or otherwise) provide the information on the order of the spline which is used to fit the model?

items.title: gridsearch fails with grid of n_splines
items.body:
Hi, 
I found an error that was not occurring in a previous version (before .5 I think). I'm currently using version 0.7.0

Here is some data:
n_data = 40
X = np.random.uniform(0, 3 * np.pi, n_data)
Y = np.sin(X) + np.random.normal(0, .4, n_data)

This works fine:
m.gridsearch(X[:, None], Y, lam=np.arange(5, 31, 5))

However, if I call
m.gridsearch(X[:, None], Y, lam=np.arange(5, 31, 5), n_splines=np.arange(5, 31, 5)) 

then I can no longer use object m. For example, with
m.summary() 

I get the error AttributeError: GAM has not been fitted. Call fit first.

Cheers,
Ricardo

items.title: Interactions between features in the GAM
items.body:
Nowhere obvious to leave this, so here we are. You asked for feedback. I've been using pyGAM for a while now, on and off, as it fits better into my workflow than R does. 

One thing that isn't clear to me is how you instruct the GAM to consider interactions between features. In R's "mgcv" package you build a GAM something like this:

```
mod <- gam(response ~ s(A, k=k1, bs="tp")
           +s(B, k=k1, bs="tp")
           +s(A,B, k=k2, bs="tp"),					
           data=training)
```
 A and B must be columns in the ```training``` dataframe. The ```+s(A,B, k=k2, bs="tp")``` indicates you want to look not just at A and B in isolation, but interactions between them. I'm no expert in GAMs, and hence I can't say how that interaction is actually handled. 

```summary(mod)``` describes the strength of the interaction, for instance, the ```s(A,B) 11.757 12.000 563.092  <2e-16 ***``` line in this:
```
Family: Beta regression(10.739) 
Link function: logit 

Formula:
eval(parse(text = responseName)) ~ s(A, k = k1, bs = "tp") + 
    s(B, k = k1, bs = "tp") + s(A, B, k = k2, bs = "tp")
<environment: 0x7fe9ac5898b0>

Parametric coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)  2.88340    0.04347   66.33   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

Approximate significance of smooth terms:
          edf Ref.df  Chi.sq p-value    
s(A)    6.585  8.109 810.041  <2e-16 ***
s(B)    1.006  1.010   4.917   0.027 *  
s(A,B) 11.757 12.000 563.092  <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

R-sq.(adj) =  0.934   Deviance explained = 98.1%
-REML = -2685.5  Scale est. = 1         n = 400
```

My feeling is that just supplying the features to pyGAM does not induce a modelling of interactions between them. I am doing this to build heatmaps of a response to two features (hence, 3D data rather than the 2D response-feature line graphs you have in your examples). My heatmaps looked "blocky", with contours on the heatmap being almost entirely vertical and horizontal. When I add additional features, multiplying the first two features together, or subtracting one from the other (hence crudely defining interactions) my heatmaps looked much more fluid. 

So, long story short, can you instruct pyGAM to look for interactions in the same way that R does, rather than the naive method I attempted (adding extra features)? If this is already implemented, could you add an example to show other users?

Many thanks for your efforts on this project.

items.title: Is it possible to return the feature functions?
items.body:
Thanks for developing a great tool!
I would like to be able to return the feature functions f_i() that are built using penalized B splines.
Is this possible?
I appreciate your help.

items.title: Assertion error in GAM._mask() method
items.body:
Thank you for developing this package. I encountered the following error when using the gridsearch method on a PoissonGAM:

``` AssertionError: increase regularization ```

I was honestly fairly confused as to how to proceed and I tried changing nearly all the parameter settings in the gridsearch function as well as the instantiation of the PoissonGAM (in a way that seemed to make sense) to no avail. 

Could more description be added to this message to help users debug the issue?

FWIW, I am trying to use the PoissonGAM to do histogram smoothing, as described in the README. I have previously gotten it to work on very similar data, but the previously discussed error arises on this particular dataset. (If you have any notes on what I should do to correct this specific error, that help would be greatly appreciated).

Below is the full traceback (and some preceding RuntimeWarnings) generated when this AssertionError is raised. Thanks for the help.

```
/Users/jreinhold/Code/pyGAM/pygam/links.py:196: RuntimeWarning: overflow encountered in exp
  return np.exp(lp)
/Users/jreinhold/Code/pyGAM/pygam/pygam.py:941: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in multiply
  self.distribution.V(mu=mu) *

/Users/jreinhold/Code/pyGAM/pygam/pygam.py:963: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in greater_equal

2018-06-13 15:27:32,417 - __main__ - ERROR - increase regularization
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/Users/jreinhold/Research/Prince/code/intensity-normalization/intensity_normalization/normalize/whitestripe.py", line 136, in whitestripe
```

items.title: Gridsearch with only a single LAM parameter
items.body: We're using pyGAM as a way to extract an array of features (the GAM coefficients) to characterise a distribution. We noticed that the first of the default LAM parameters is almost always chosen. It would speed up the feature extraction significantly if we could constrain the gridsearch to a single LAM parameter (currently the length of the vector has to be > 1).

```
/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sklearn/base.py in clone(estimator, safe)
     61     for name, param in six.iteritems(new_object_params):
     62         new_object_params[name] = clone(param, safe=False)
---> 63     new_object = klass(**new_object_params)
     64     params_set = new_object.get_params(deep=False)

TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'verbose'
```

items.title: Stepping with discrete numerical data
items.body:
I have this data: 
[nyears_uniqueness.csv.txt](https://github.com/dswah/pyGAM/files/1761344/nyears_uniqueness.csv.txt)

When I use pyGAM to smooth it, I get some strange results:

```python
gam = LinearGAM(n_splines=4)
gam.fit(df[['nyears']], df.uniqueness)
# /home/naught101/miniconda3/envs/science/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pygam/pygam.py:1172: UserWarning: detected catergorical data for feature 0
#  self._validate_data_dep_params(X)

x_pred = np.linspace(min(df.nyears), max(df.nyears), num=100)
y_pred = gam.predict(x_pred)    

df.plot.scatter(x='nyears', y='uniqueness')
ax = gca()
ax.plot(x_pred, y_pred)    
```

![figure_1-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/167164/36712257-121e3c16-1bdc-11e8-9b4c-a78bbb1f3290.png)

When I try plotting the same data in R, I get a much smoother curve. I'm not sure if that's just a matter of the defaults being more appropriate for the data, or if this is a bug in pyGAM. If, do you have any suggestions for how to improve the pyGAM plot?

items.title: PoissonGAM fails with dimension mismatch warning depending on n_splines
items.body:
Using a grid search and several options for n_splines, some fits fail due to a dimension mismatch. 

```
gam = PoissonGAM(dtype='numerical').gridsearch(X, y, n_splines=np.arange(4,10))

....

  return (mu**y) * np.exp(-mu) / sp.misc.factorial(y)
 50% (3 of 6) |#############              | Elapsed Time: 0:00:00 ETA:  0:00:00/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pygam/pygam.py:1888: UserWarning: shapes (120,240) and (239,120) not aligned: 240 (dim 1) != 239 (dim 0)
on model:
PoissonGAM(callbacks=[Deviance(), Diffs(), Accuracy()], 
   constraints=None, dtype='numerical', fit_intercept=True, 
   fit_linear=False, fit_splines=True, lam=0.6, max_iter=100, 
   n_splines=7, penalties='auto', spline_order=3, tol=0.0001)
skipping...

  warnings.warn(msg)
 66% (4 of 6) |##################         | Elapsed Time: 0:00:00 ETA:  0:00:00/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pygam/pygam.py:1888: UserWarning: shapes (137,260) and (259,123) not aligned: 260 (dim 1) != 259 (dim 0)
on model:
PoissonGAM(callbacks=[Deviance(), Diffs(), Accuracy()], 
   constraints=None, dtype='numerical', fit_intercept=True, 
   fit_linear=False, fit_splines=True, lam=0.6, max_iter=100, 
   n_splines=8, penalties='auto', spline_order=3, tol=0.0001)
skipping...

...

```

Training a LinearGAM model using the same dataset and grid search options does not give rise to the same error.

```
gam = LinearGAM(dtype='numerical').gridsearch(X, y, n_splines=np.arange(4,10))
100% (6 of 6) |###########################| Elapsed Time: 0:00:00 Time: 0:00:00
```
Does this occur because there are more coefficients than data? If so, a more informative warning would be helpful.

items.title: Prediciton intervals not working as expected
items.body:
I am using PyGAM to measure changes in volume in certain body structures across age ranges and wanted to validate that the prediction intervals were working as I expected using a simulated dataset using the normal distribution. I use a normal distribution to synthesize the test dataset andt the values of the prediction intervals are not matching the percentiles of the normal database. 

I would expect that if I calculate a prediction interval with width = 0.8, this would give me values equivalent to the 10th and 90th percentiles of the dataset, with 10% of the synthesised samples lying below the lower prediction interval curve and 10% lying above the higher one. This is however not what I find.

I have attached a jupyter notebook demonstrating my findings with an explanation:
[PyGAM intervals.ipynb.zip](https://github.com/dswah/pyGAM/files/1632655/PyGAM.intervals.ipynb.zip)

I would like to know if I am misinterpreting the way the prediction interval works, misusing the library, or if there is a problem in the library.

I wanted to embed 'pyGAM' into my own python program, but it would have a progress bar in each loop, so that it would take a long time to run. If I can remove it and not let it run, the program will run very fast. (The screenshot of issue is below.)
So, how can I get rid of progress bar in your pyGAM program without changing other functions ? 
Coul you help me? Thanks in advance!

![issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18735308/34613918-95996520-f26a-11e7-8cfa-58ed112a4940.png)

items.title: Issues with examples...
items.body:
There seem to be a few issues with the examples provided which may confuse someone:
- The data sets are not actually loaded within the example code
- Simulation from the posterior does not appear to work for LinearGAMs. Particularly I get the error:
`AttributeError: 'LinearGAM' object has no attribute 'sample'`
- Matplotlib usage is 'fast and loose'. For example, it is not imported, plt.show() is assumed or interactive use is assumed, etc.
- Nice features like confidence_intervals are not demonstrated.
- There is no code at all for the 'Linear Extrapolation' section. It may be most useful to demonstrate this using a simple time series data set.

Wonderful work so far!

items.title: Recurring error in links.py due to Numpy
items.body:
Hi!

I observe a recurring error message when using GammaGAM and InvGaussianGAM: "ValueError: Integers to negative integer powers are not allowed".

This seems to be generated by for example the row 304 in links.py, where the power is applied as follows: "mu**-2" (but such powers occurs more than once in this script).

It seems that Numpy doesn't allow this but would allow "mu**-2.0". See here for more info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43287311/why-cant-i-raise-to-a-negative-power-in-numpy

Would be nice if you could implement this quick fix, adding a ".0" :) Thanks!

items.title: Density-dependent confidence intervals?
items.body:
Is it possible to get density-dependent or input-dependent confidence intervals?

For example:

```python
import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
from pygam import LinearGAM

gam = LinearGAM()

x = np.random.random(1000)*10
y = 5/(x+1) * np.random.randn(1000)

gam.fit(x, y)

plt.scatter(x, y)

x_pred = np.linspace(min(x), max(x), num=100)
y_pred = gam.predict(x_pred)
y_int = gam.prediction_intervals(x_pred, width=.95)

ax = plt.gca()
ax.plot(x_pred, y_pred, 'r-')
ax.fill_between(x_pred, y_int[:, 0], y_int[:, 1], alpha=0.1, facecolor='r')
```

Produces this: 

![gam test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/167164/33690359-4303cb60-db37-11e7-95a1-4757d50011c2.png)
 
But these confidence intervals don't seem all that useful. Is there a way to get confidence intervals that change dependent on the local conditions?

items.title: Questions: Categorical
items.body:
Great lib! I saw some nice results on a model I built (regression). I am curious though:

1) I see warnings about features being categorical when there are none - how is this determined and what is the impact?

2) If a new observation has a level outside the training set, an error occurs. One way I *THINK* to handle this and make sure scoring doesnt fail, is to clip all predictors to the min and max observed when training the model - is this correct? 

3) Related to #2 is there a way to export the expected ranges from the model object or best to just use min and max of training records for each predictor?

items.title: SVD can fail when features are duplicates
items.body:
for example, if we add a column of ones to our input data and pyGAM has `fit_intercept=True`, then we can get a SVD error.

There should be 2 checks:
- no 2 columns of X are the same
- if there is a constant column, then set fit_intercept=False

items.title: is the LogisticGAM example in the README missing a *?
items.body:
I am able to reproduce the LogisticGAM example in the README if I put an unpacking operator `*` in front of `confi` in the second `plot` command. Is that `*` missing, or is my error a result of having a different version of Python (I'm using 3.5.3) and matplotlib (I'm using 2.0.2)?

Without that `*` inserted I get: `ValueError: x and y must have same first dimension, but have shapes (500,) and (1, 500, 2)`. `confi` is a list containing a (500, 2)-shape `numpy.array`.

Here's my full working reproduction of the LogisticGAM example in `README.md`:
```
from pyGAM.pygam import LogisticGAM
default = pd.read_csv(os.path.join('pyGAM', 'datasets', 'default.csv'), index_col=0)
default_numeric = default.applymap(lambda x: {'No': 0, 'Yes': 1}.get(x, x))
X = default_numeric.loc[:, ['student', 'balance', 'income']]
y = default_numeric.loc[:, ['default']]
gam = LogisticGAM().gridsearch(X, y);
XX = generate_X_grid(gam)

fig, axs = plt.subplots(1, 3)
titles = ['student', 'balance', 'income']

for i, ax in enumerate(axs):
    pdep, confi = gam.partial_dependence(XX, feature=i+1, width=.95)
    print(np.array(pdep).shape, np.array(confi).shape)

    ax.plot(XX[:, i], pdep)
    ax.plot(XX[:, i], *confi, c='r', ls='--')
    ax.set_title(titles[i])
```
The only changes I made were to add the `*` in `ax.plot(XX[:, i], *confi, c='r', ls='--')` and to create `X` and `y` from `default.csv` which weren't shown in the documentation.

items.title: Add method for simulating from the posterior (or just add an example to the documentation)
items.body:
Estimating the mean and confidence intervals (using `prediction_intervals`) is great. In some cases, it can be useful to simulate from the posterior distribution of the model's coefficients. An example is given in pages 242–243 of [1].

I think the following code snippet does the trick for a `LinearGAM`:
```
def simulate_from_posterior(linear_gam, X, n_simulations):
    """Simulate from the posterior of a LinearGAM a certain number of times.

    Inputs
    ------
    linear_gam : pyGAM.LinearGAM

    X : array of shape (n_samples, n_features)

    n_simulations : int
        The number of simulations from the posterior to compute

    Returns
    -------
    simulations : array of shape (n_samples, n_simulations)
    """
    beta_replicates = np.random.multivariate_normal(
        linear_gam.coef_, linear_gam.statistics_['cov'], size=n_simulations)
    return linear_gam._modelmat(X).dot(beta_replicates.T)
```
I'm not sure if this should be added as an example in the documentation or added to the code (or both).

To implement this in general, I think we'd want to add a method for each `Distribution` that draws a certain number of samples (called `sample` or `random_variate`?), so we'd have a `NormalDist.sample`, `BinomialDist.sample`, and so on. Then the `GAM.simulate` could just call `self.dist.sample(self.coef_, self.statistics['cov'], size=n_simulations)`? I'm not sure yet how to best handle the link functions for these simulations...

As pointed out on pages 256–257 of [1], this procedure simulates the coefficients _conditioned on the smoothing parameters_, lambda (`lam`). To actually simulate from the coefficients, one may use bootstrap samples to get simulations of the coefficients and of the smoothing parameters; an example is given on page 257 of [1].

[1] S. Wood. Generalized Additive Models: An Introduction with R (First Edition). Chapman & Hall/CRC Texts in Statistical Science. Taylor & Francis, 2006.

items.title: Poisson model does not accept weights or interval of time
items.body:
When using Poisson models the data to be fitted is the number of events per unit of time, but the interval of time can be variable for each sample. There are some possible solutions for this:

1. Add a `time` parameter to the fit/predict method
2. Add a `time` feature to the data that will be used by fit/predict
3. Divide the observed number of events by interval of time and weight each sample with the interval of time

However, from what I saw in the source code none of this solutions is available right now.

items.title: should allow more splines than observations
items.body:
as we thought, it should be possible to have more splines than observations.

slide 21 from crash-course pt 2 says so :)
```
Properties of P-splines
• Penalty P
j(∆
dαj)2
• Limit for strong smoothing is a polynomial of degree d − 1
• Interpolation: polynomial of degree 2d − 1
• Extrapolation: polynomial of degree d − 1
• Conservation of moments of degree up to d − 1
• Many more B-splines then observations allowed <-----
• The penalty does the work!
• (Software demo: PSPlay psplines)
```
